Derek James wrote:

>On Fri, 09 Jul 2004 22:08:33 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>Yeh, in my experience this is an often encountered problem. I've
>>tinkered with solutions similar to your's of averaraging past fitness
>>scores, and although I've never been entirely happy with it I think it's
>>the best way of solving the problem if no appropriate deterministic
>>evaluation is available.
>>    
>>
>
>Well, one thing to do is not even handle the stagnant species issue.
>:)  We have yet to implement this aspect of NEAT.  After reading on
>this list that it has helped with performance gains, we went back and
>looked at our evolving populations, to see what was going on with
>species.  We were afraid that perhaps stagnant species were
>overstaying their welcome and that we weren't getting good turnover in
>the population.
>
>But that turned out to not be the case.  We seem to have plenty of
>dynamism in our populations...that is, new species arising and old
>ones going extinct.  We also don't clamp the number of species, so we
>often have 20-30 species in an evolving population.
>  
>
Yeh it depends on how the experiments are progressing. If there is a 
steady increase in fitness then old species will tend to die out 
naturally as the new species become fitter and take up more space. If 
however the search gets stuck then you might be able to give it a 
kick-start by eliminating some old species and making space for some of 
the newer ones. I guess we're covering old ground here slightly, but 
personally I have a tendency to forget this stuff if it's not written 
down or mentioned occasionally.

>>Actually I've been quietly working on Tic-Tac-Toe, following in Derek
>>and Philips footsteps, 
>>    
>>
>
>Will you be posting ongoing results somewhere...at least here? :)
>  
>
Yup, I'm starting to get somewhere now so I should be able to write up 
some results soon. Basically I am re-using the strategies from your 
experiments, although the player code is mostly re-written/re-organised 
it still represents the same strategies, but with some extra randomness. 
So e.g. where you had, say, a strategy that tests for an open corner and 
plays it, I basically pick randomly from the available open corners, 
rather than always testing them in order and playing the first that is 
available. I think you did this in some places and not others, so I 
changed the code to always play randomly if possible/appropriate.

So I have all of your strategies ported - Best, Forkable, Center, Random 
and Bad. One evaluation plays each strategy with half the games playing 
first go. I wasn't playing as many games as you so I've just increased 
this. Another idea I got from reading an article on the internet was to 
punish for a loss instead of allocating 0. So now I allocate a score of 
-10 for a loss, if the total fitness comes out negative then I just 
return 0. I think this might help things along a bit more - time will tell.

>>So I thought maybe I should introduce an element of randomness, but then
>>I encounter the problem of some NN's getting an unrepresenitive score
>>through good or bad luck. Another ay of minimising this problem is to
>>play more games per evaluation, which has the same or similar effect as
>>averaging scores from previous evals.
>>    
>>
>
>Well, because the board is so small and games are played so quickly,
>random and semi-random opponents are a pretty good idea.  In our LBP
>for GECCO, each generations our networks were playing 100 games each
>against 5 difference hand-coded players, all of which had some degree
>of random play.  So there was a fair amount of noise in the
>evaluation, but good, solid play bore out because there were so many
>games played for each evaluation.
>
Yeh good points. So I might just see some good players with my current 
setup then, just by increasing the number of games per evaluation.

>  This type of approach obviously
>isn't going to work very well with much larger board game domains,
>though.
>  
>
Indeed. Designing good strategies to evolve against is definitely a big 
part of the battle. Even if you have a perfect strategy like your BEST, 
you cannot assume that the resulting NNs will also exhibit the same 
ability to at least force a draw and also win against poor players. In 
fact if you just evolved againt BEST then the NNs won't know anything 
about winning, they will have evolved to always force a draw against a 
good player.

>Although I think *some* degree of randomness needs to be introduced in
>opponent play, no matter what approach you're taking, or you're
>probably going to be evolving extremely brittle strategies.
>  
>
Yes. One unexpected (and potentially poor) move by an opponent could put 
you NN into unknown territory and cause it to loose.

BTW Derek, your LBP experiments were fairly short in duration, 200 gens 
as I recall. Did you do any longer runs to try and evolve a perfect 
Tic-Tac-Toe player?


Colin.
